titleStmt.title: Mining Adaptively Frequent Closed Unlabeled Rooted Trees in Data Streams

analytic.title: Mining Adaptively Frequent Closed Unlabeled Rooted Trees in Data Streams

application.ref: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Data Streams
div.p: Sequence is potentially infinite Include all the trees whose support is no less than min_sup Linear Relaxed Interval:The support space of all subpatterns can be divided into n = 1/ε r intervals, where ε r is a user-specified relaxed factor, and each interval can be denoted by
div.formula: I i = [l i , u i ), where l i = (n − i) * ε r ≥ 0, u i = (n − i + 1) * ε r ≤ 1 and i ≤ n.
div.p: Linear Relaxed closed subpattern t: if and only if there exists no proper superpattern t of t such that their suports belong to the same interval I i .
As the number of closed frequent patterns is not linear with respect support, we introduce a new relaxed support:
Logarithmic Relaxed Interval:The support space of all subpatterns can be divided into n = 1/ε r intervals, where ε r is a user-specified relaxed factor, and each interval can be denoted by
div.formula: I i = [l i , u i ), where l i = c i , u i = c i+1 − 1 and i ≤ n.
div.p: Logarithmic Relaxed closed subpattern t: if and only if there exists no proper superpattern t of t such that their suports belong to the same interval I i .

figure.head: Closed
figure.figDesc: Frequent Tree Pattern (CS): Include no tree which has a super-tree with the same support CS ⊆ FS Closed Frequent Tree Mining provides a compact representation of frequent trees without loss of information Introduction Problem Given a data stream D of rooted, unlabelled and unordered trees, find frequent closed trees.

figure.head: Figure :
figure.figDesc: ADATREENAT Uses ADWIN to monitor change ADWIN An adaptive sliding window whose size is recomputed online according to the rate of change observed.ADWIN has rigorous guarantees (theorems)On ratio of false positives and negatives On the relation of the size of the current window and Time on experiments on ordered trees on TN1 dataset
Given a dataset of trees, find the complete set of frequent subtrees Frequent Tree Pattern (FS):
figure.table:
High amount of data: sublinear space
High speed of arrival: sublinear time per example
Tree Mining
Mining frequent trees is becoming an important task Applications:
chemical informatics computer vision text retrieval bioinformatics Web analysis.
Many link-based structures may be studied formally by means of unordered trees Introduction
What Is Tree Pattern Mining?
